en_first_half: In the population of Transylvania there are four distinct nationalities: Saxons in the South, and mixed with them the Wallachs, who are the descendants of the Dacians; Magyars in the West, and Szekelys in the East and North. I am going among the latter, who claim to be descended from Attila and the Huns. This may be so, for when the
en_second_half: Magyars conquered the country in the eleventh century they found the Huns settled in it. I read that every known superstition in the world is gathered into the horseshoe of the Carpathians, as if it were the centre of some sort of imaginative whirlpool; if so my stay may be very interesting. (Mem., I must ask the Count all about them.)
en_results_raw: Magyars settled in Hungary in the tenth century, the Szekelys, as they call themselves, were left behind to keep watch over the frontier. They are a wild, warlike race, and have retained many of the customs and superstitions of their forefathers. They live in a picturesque and rugged country, and their history is full of romantic incidents. I am going to see their principal town, which is called Mediaş, and is situated in a narrow valley between two ranges of the Eastern Carpathians. The journey is not without its dangers, for the passes are often blocked by heavy snows in winter, and the roads are frequented by bands of brigands. However, I have engaged a trustworthy guide, and I am confident that we shall reach our destination in safety. The Szekelys are a people of great interest to the ethnologist, and I am eager to study their customs and traditions. Their language, too, is a curious mixture of Hungarian and Rumanian, with a sprinkling of words derived from the ancient Dacian. I shall endeavour to collect some specimens of it for comparison with the Magyar and Rumanian dialects. The journey promises to be both instructive and exciting, and I am looking forward to it with great anticipation.

es_results_raw: los escequelios se refugiaron en las montañas, donde mantuvieron su identidad cultural más intacta. Según las leyendas locales, estos pueblos mantuvieron vínculos con sus raíces húnicas a través de tradiciones orales y prácticas culturales que han sobrevivido a través de los siglos. La región escequelia se caracteriza por su topografía montañosa y su clima frío, lo que ha permitido la conservación de su identidad cultural aislada. Los escequelios son conocidos por su habilidad para la agricultura en tierras escarpadas y por su arte tradicional, que incluye textiles elaborados a mano y música folclórica. A pesar de las invasiones y dominaciones a lo largo de la historia, los escequelios han mantenido firme su conexión con su pasado ancestral, lo que les ha permitido preservar su lengua, costumbres y tradiciones. La presencia de estos pueblos es un recordatorio vivo de la rica diversidad étnica de Transilvania y de la resistencia cultural ante las fuerzas de homogeneización. La investigación sobre sus raíces húnicas continúa ofreciendo nuevas perspectivas sobre la historia de la región y la influencia de los pueblos migratorios en la formación de las identidades culturales actuales.
